messageBody:
## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for July 24, 2019 - July 30, 2019
##
## Message Issue Date: 2019-07-31T20:12:22Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2019-07-24T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2019-07-30T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20190731-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period. There were no major solar flares or coronal mass ejections.  

Geomagnetic activity was below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=3 for the reporting period. The highest value of Kp=3 occurred during the synoptic periods 2019-07-30T12:00Z-18:00Z and 2019-07-30T21:00Z-24:00Z. This slight elevation in geomagnetic activity is associated with the arrival of a weak coronal hole high speed stream detected by ACE at L1 around 2019-07-30.  The solar wind speed reached values of ~500 km/s on 2019-07-30.  

STEREO A IMPACT and PLASTIC instruments detected the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream around 2019-07-24.  Solar wind speed reached values of ~600 km/s on 2019-07-24.  The arrival of another coronal hole high speed stream was detected by STEREO A IMPACT and PLASTIC instruments around 2019-07-30.  The solar wind speed reached values of ~550 km/s on 2019-07-30.  

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 10^5 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed 

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2019-07-31T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2019-08-06T23:59Z

The solar activity is expected to be low for the upcoming week. There are no major active regions present on the solar surface. Geomagnetic activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week due to the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream around 2019-08-04.

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score


NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center/Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC, http://swrc.gsfc.nasa.gov ) Disclaimer

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 10^5 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period.

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for July 10, 2019 - July 16, 2019
##
## Message Issue Date: 2019-07-17T21:32:58Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2019-07-10T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2019-07-16T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20190717-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period. There were no significant flares or CMEs.  

Geomagnetic activity was at minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=5 for the reporting period.  The highest value of Kp=5 occurred during the synoptic period of 2019-07-10T6:00Z-9:00Z.  This elevation in geomagnetic activity was associated with a continuing coronal hole high speed stream from 2019-07-08. 

On 2019-07-16 the STEREO-A/IMPACT and PLASTIC instruments detected the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream at STEREO A, with a peak speed of about 550 km/s.

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt crossed the threshold level of 10^5 pfu starting at 2019-07-10T15:25Z. These significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt detected by GOES were associated with the high speed stream starting on 2019-07-08 (see notifications 20190710-AL-001, 20190710-AL-002 and 20190712-AL-001).

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low to moderate this week due to the elevated energetic electrons fluxes on the Earth's outer radiation belt described above.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed 

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2019-07-17T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2019-07-23T23:59Z

The solar activity is expected to be low for the upcoming week. There are no major active regions visible on the solar disk.  Geomagnetic activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week due to the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream around 2019-07-23.

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Continued Radiation Belt Enhancement
##
## Message Issue Date: 2019-07-12T18:05:53Z
## Message ID: 20190712-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

This is an update to the notification with ID 20190710-AL-002. Energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt continue to be significantly elevated. GOES "greater than 0.8 MeV" integral electron flux first exceeded 10^5 pfu starting at 2019-07-10T15:25Z and has continued to be above or near the threshold.

The elevated energetic electron flux levels are caused by  high speed stream starting at 2019-07-08T18:30Z.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2019-07-10T15:25:00-RBE-001. 

## Notes: 



NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center/Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC, http://swrc.gsfc.nasa.gov ) Disclaimer

Data and/or information from the NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center/Space Weather Research Center is provided "as is" without any warranty of any kind, either expressed, implied, or statutory, including, but not limited to, any warranty that the data and/or information will conform to specifications, any implied warranties of merchantability, fitness for a particular purpose, or freedom from infringement, any warranty that the information will be error free, or any warranty that documentation, if provided, will conform to the data and/or information. ## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for July 03, 2019 - July 09, 2019
##
## Message Issue Date: 2019-07-12T06:46:50Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2019-07-03T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2019-07-09T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20190712-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period.  There were no significant flares or CMEs.  

Geomagnetic activity was at minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=5 for the reporting period.  The highest value of Kp=5 occurred during the synoptic period of 2019-07-09T18:00Z-21:00Z.  This elevation in geomagnetic activity was associated with a coronal hole high speed stream detected by ACE at L1 around 2019-07-08.  The solar wind speed reached values of ~650 km/s on 2019-07-09.  

STEREO A IMPACT and PLASTIC instruments detected the arrival of a possible small coronal hole high speed stream around 2019-07-08.  Solar wind speed reached values of ~500 km/s on 2019-07-08.   

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 10^5 pfu for this reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2019-07-10T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2019-07-16T23:59Z

The solar activity is expected to be low for the upcoming week.   There are no major active regions visible on the solar disk.  Geomagnetic activity is expected to be moderate for the upcoming week due to the effects of the coronal hole high speed stream described above.  Currently, the > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux levels detected at GOES are elevated and crossed the threshold of 10^5 pfu at 2019-07-10T15:25Z (see notifications 20190710-AL-001 and 20190710-AL-002).  Some additional geomagnetic activity may occur around 2019-07-16 due to the arrival of a small diffuse coronal hole high speed stream.  

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Radiation Belt Enhancement
##
## Message Issue Date: 2019-07-10T15:54:38Z
## Message ID: 20190710-AL-002
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES "greater than 0.8 MeV" integral electron flux is above 10^5 pfu starting at 2019-07-10T15:25Z.

The elevated energetic electron flux levels are caused by the high speed stream starting at 2019-07-08T18:30Z.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2019-07-10T15:25:00-RBE-001.

## Notes:

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Possible Interplanetary Shock
##
## Message Issue Date: 2019-07-09T00:37:06Z
## Message ID: 20190709-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Possible interplanetary shock detected by ACE at L1 at 2019-07-08T18:30Z. 

Strong magnetospheric compression and geomagnetic storm possible. 

Activity ID: 2019-07-08T18:30:00-IPS-001.

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for June 26, 2019 - July 02, 2019
##
## Message Issue Date: 2019-07-03T22:56:53Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2019-06-26T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2019-07-02T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20190703-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period.  There were no significant flares or CMEs.  

Geomagnetic activity was well below moderate levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=3 for the reporting period.

Starting on 2019-06-27 a high speed stream was observed at STEREO A with a peak speed of about 550 km/s.

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 10^5 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
None Observed  

Non-Earth directed:
None Observed   

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2019-07-03T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2019-07-09T23:59Z

The solar is expected to be low for the upcoming week.  The geomagnetic activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week due to the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream around 2019-07-05.  

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
